newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SM Summit says stampers not from raid.
newsitem.headline: SM Summit says stampers not from raid.

text.p: Compact disc maker SM Summit Ltd said on Monday the CD-ROM stampers cited as evidence in a piracy suit against Summit were not obtained in a raid.
"These CD-ROM stampers were not taken from the company's premises during the raid on 12 August 1997," it said in a statement to the Stock Exchange of Singapore (SES).
The company and its subsidiary Summit CD Manufacture Pte Ltd (SCM) have been named as defendants in a High Court suit for infringing copyright and trademark, it said.
The action was initiated by Adobe Systems Inc, Autodesk Inc and Microsoft Corp.

The Summit statement said the three alleged Summit and SCM infringed certain copyrights and trademarks in relation to not more than five CD-ROM stampers alleged to have been made by the company and SCM sometime in April this year.
Business Software Alliance (BSA), which had filed the suit on behalf of the three American companies, later said that the stampers obtained by them were from investigations and not from the raid.
BSA had said it had managed to obtain eight stampers. Each can be used to replicate tens of thousands of CD-ROMs.
The plaintiffs are claiming damages, injunctions and costs.
Summit said it had engaged Davinder Singh, senior counsel of Drew & Napier to defend this action which it plans to vigorously contest.
